content.1: Lo, mine eye hath seen all
content.3: Surely I would speak to the Almighty, and I desire to reason with God.
content.5: O that ye would altogether hold your peace! and it should be your wisdom.
content.6: Hear now my reasoning, and hearken to the pleadings of my lips.
content.7: Will ye speak wickedly for God? and talk deceitfully for him?
content.8: Will ye accept his person? will ye contend for God?
content.9: Is it good that he should search you out? or as one man mocketh another, do ye
content.10: He will surely reprove you, if ye do secretly accept persons.
content.11: Shall not his excellency make you afraid? and his dread fall upon you?
content.13: Hold your peace, let me alone, that I may speak, and let come on me what
content.14: Wherefore do I take my flesh in my teeth, and put my life in mine hand?
content.15: Though he slay me, yet will I trust in him: but I will maintain mine own ways before him.
content.17: Hear diligently my speech, and my declaration with your ears.
content.21: Withdraw thine hand far from me: and let not thy dread make me afraid.
content.22: Then call thou, and I will answer: or let me speak, and answer thou me.
content.24: Wherefore hidest thou thy face, and holdest me for thine enemy?
content.25: Wilt thou break a leaf driven to and fro? and wilt thou pursue the dry stubble?
content.26: For thou writest bitter things against me, and makest me to possess the iniquities of my youth.
content.27: Thou puttest my feet also in the stocks, and lookest narrowly unto all my paths; thou settest a print upon the heels of my feet.
content.28: And he, as a rotten thing, consumeth, as a garment that is moth eaten.
